esteem is generally preserved, whereas in an MDE, feelings of worthlessness
and self-loathing are common. If self-derogatory ideation is present in grief, it
typically involves perceived failings vis-à-vis the deceased (e.g., not visiting
frequently enough, not telling the deceased how much he or she was loved). If
a bereaved individual thinks about death and dying, such thoughts are gener-
ally focused on the deceased and possibly about “joining” the deceased,
whereas in an MDE, such thoughts are focused on ending one’s own life be-
cause of feeling worthless, undeserving of life, or unable to cope with the pain
of depression.
